It is not as if the Ipswich City Council have not made applications; it is not as if they have not done their part of the job, their end of the bargain. They have done that. They have done the work; they have done the research, the surveys. There would not be a person in Ipswich who would not tell you that the most dangerous intersection in Ipswich is at the corner of Cemetery Road and Whitehill Road at Raceview. This intersection has been the cause of many tragic deaths and many very serious accidents, and every time the council put up the priority list of roads they need black spot funding for the Commonwealth government ignores those pleas. The federal government has on other occasions provided funding for black spot programs, and certainly everybody does appreciate it, because black spot funding is an extremely important part of the federal government’s responsibility to look after people in our country areas and in the city as well. But in the case of this particular road I am at a loss as to why this government refuses to accept the local authority’s determination of it as the highest priority, as the most dangerous road. In the past we have had, as I said, other roads fixed. In fact, there have been a number of them in previous submissions for funding. Unfortunately in last year’s last round of funding there was no money given at all to Ipswich City Council for any black spot funding programs. There was one road in Ipswich for which funding was applied for by the state government and, quite happily, that road at Bundamba was fixed under the black spot funding program, for about $200,000. In the past, the federal government has given about $680,000 to upgrade other roads. But I have the list of roads here, and I make an absolutely desperate plea to the minister to go back and have a look at these roads on my list. At the top of that list is the intersection of Cemetery Road and Whitehill Road at Raceview. There is the Old Logan Road, which is Addison Road and Cairns Road, at Camira; Bertha Street and Mill Street at Goodna; Ripley Road and Reif Street at Flinders View; Smiths Road and William Street at Goodna; Darling Street MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Adjournment

speaker: Mr Ripoll (Oxley) (12.50 P.m.)
theText: I am completely outraged and disgusted at the inacand Waghorn Street in Ipswich; and Ripley Road, Raceview Street and Edwards Street at Flinders View. All of these are important but none more so than the intersection of Cemetery Road and Whitehill Road. This road, if you saw it, Mr Deputy Speaker, would make you cringe. When you see this road you can understand why it is so dangerous, why it is so desperately in need of funding. I would make the assessment that the reason the federal government is not funding this road is not that it is callous-some people might think that; I do not believe that. I think it is just a case of money, a simple formula of money, because this intersection, unlike others, would cost $2½ million to fix. It needs lights; it needs a fair bit of work to make it safe. We have had in the past budgets up to $680,000 in totality, but since 2000 Ipswich City Council has applied for this particular road and it has been ignored or overlooked, and I can only come up with two possible reasons: either the government completely believes that this is irrelevant and does not worry about the safety of people-and I do not believe that to be true-or it is about the money and the government cannot afford it. But how can this government not afford $2½ million when it has a $7½ billion surplus-and, as we know, Mr Deputy Speaker, next year it will be even bigger, because this is the highest-taxing government in our history? That is why it has such a big surplus. When you collect a lot of money and do not give it back by spending it on people you are going to have a lot of money in the bank. That is what effectively the federal government has. I have always had the view from a very early age that governments are not in the business of scrounging money and putting it away for a rainy day. The rainy day is today. The government collects taxes on behalf of the people to spend it back on them for their good, and there is no better good than to try under the black spot funding program to fix extremely dangerous intersections, such as the one at Cemetery Road and Whitehill Road. I am not a lone voice on this issue. The member for Blair has actually gone out there and said that this is important too. The Liberal member for Blair, Cameron Thompson, has said that this is really important and this road should be funded. But he sort of tries a bit of a cop-out: he says that these are council roads and there is no sign there that says this road should be fixed. Maybe he is blind, maybe there is no sign, but go and talk to anyone in his electorate in Ipswich and they will tell you what is important: that road needs to be fixed. I would say that the government needs to take action-(Time expired) Tourism: White Paper Ms GAMBARO (Petrie) (12.55 p.m.)-I rise to speak about the importance of the tourism industry in electorates all around Australia, and particularly in my electorate of Petrie where some 40 per cent of tourism related businesses exist and almost four per cent of the work force is employed in the tourism industry. I particularly acknowledge the fine work done by the Minister for Small Business and Tourism, Joe Hockey, in delivering his policy and his white paper on tourism, which was launched last week, and the impact of that paper on the tourism industry, with the injection of $235 million over the next four years. This has been long awaited by the tourism industry and it will truly be a blueprint into the future for the industry. A number of things have occurred. A new body called Tourism Australia will be set up. It will be responsible for and incorporate a number of groups, including See Australia, and it will absorb forecasting associations as well. This means that now there will be a true direction MAIN COMMITTEE for tourism in this country. For far too long individual states have marketed their own particular tourism bodies overseas and now, with a more integrated approach, we can have Brand Australia, which is going to promote the whole of Australia as a desirable destination for international tourists to come and experience the wonders of this wonderful country. One of the main features of this marketing strategy is a huge emphasis on the international sector as well as the domestic sector. It will emphasise areas such as the food and wine sectors, and international students have also been heavily targeted. I was really pleased to learn recently that our Working Holiday Maker Program has been extended to include France. A number of young students come over here on working holiday programs and then stay on. They are a very valuable form of tourism for this country, as is the backpacker sector, which is also a huge revenue-earning area in this country. Nature tourism is also an area that has been targeted. More and more tourists are coming to our country to enjoy wonderful sights such as the Great Barrier Reef, outback Queensland and outback Australia as a whole. People are also experiencing these wonderful features in caravans. This is an area that has been targeted, as well as business tourism, cultural tourism, heritage tourism and sports tourism. One also cannot deny the incredible success of the Rugby World Cup tour recently, particularly when the revenue was close to $1 billion and something like three billion people world wide watched the coverage. But more important were the great opportunities for regional Australia from this incredible event. It meant that tourists who came out for the rugby also got to experience wonderful cities like Townsville and Wollongongplaces that they probably would never have visited had matches not been held in some of those regional centres. It has been a wonderful thing for the country generally. It is very important that we promote our country as a brand rather than individual states competing with each other. That has been the case far too often-people have thought about Australia in terms of the Sydney Harbour Bridge or Gold Coast beaches. But we have so much more to offer the international tourist who is visiting Australia. An important feature of this white paper has also been the intergovernmental agreement, and that will be discussed at COAG 2005. That includes all the states and territories coming together and working in unison to create a truly integrated policy in tourism so that the whole of Australia benefits. I congratulate the minister for the fine work that he is doing, particularly in ensuring that more events come to this country. A new body being set up as part of Tourism Australia is Events Australia. That body will work in a very coordinated way to ensure that the whole of Australia benefits from a program of events. It is also about teeing up tourism with wonderful sporting events like the rugby so you have a win-win situation from both the tourism aspect and the sporting aspect. The only winners from this are Australia and the wonderful industries and people who work in the tourism related industries that I spoke of when I started this speech. I congratulate everybody in the tourism area, and particularly the minister, for their work. Question agreed to. Main Committee adjourned at 1.01 p.m. MAIN COMMITTEE The following answers to questions were circulated: Education: Postgraduate Students (Question No. 2486) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 18 September 2003: (1) Has the Minister seen a Council of Australian Postgraduate Associations report dated 24 March 2003 titled “The Social and Economic Impact of Student Debt 2003”. (2) Can he confirm the findings of international studies cited in the report which suggest that the increasing cost of education, combined with the reduction of government financial assistance, may prevent many students from continuing with postgraduate studies; if not, why not. (3) Has the Government’s reduction of support-services and structures for students in Australia contributed to (a) insurmountable financial pressure on Australian students, and (b) poor postgraduate student completion rates in Australia; if not, why not. Dr NelsonThe Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services has transferred this question to me. The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) Yes. (2) The Australian Government has increased financial assistance for postgraduate students through the Postgraduate Education Loan Scheme (PELS) which was introduced in 2002. PELS provides a loan facility for eligible students who are enrolled in fee-paying, postgraduate non-research courses. The loan facility is similar to the deferred payment arrangements available under the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS). In 2002, the Commonwealth paid a total of $115 million to institutions on behalf of students who had elected to take out a PELS loan for their tuition fees. This benefited 11,387 equivalent full-time student units (EFTSU) (or 25,213 students), which equates to 33% of the total EFTSU enrolled in domestic fee-paying postgraduate coursework courses. Over 25,000 students took out PELS loans in 2002 while enrolments in PELS eligible courses have also shown a 20 per cent increase in 2002 over 2001, compared to a 15 per cent increase in the previous year. The findings of research undertaken by Professor Bruce Chapman of the Australian National University show that income-contingent student loan schemes support enhance student participation in higher education, concluding that “the introduction of income-contingent charging systems for higher education has the potential to protect the access of the disadvantaged”. (3) (a) The Council of Australian Postgraduate Associations report does not state that the Government has reduced support services and structures in Australia. (b) Internal research from the Department of Education Science and Training has indicated that in Australia annual postgraduate completions increased from 39,733 in 1997 to 43,122 in 2001. No completions data is yet available for 2002. Health and Ageing: Home and Community Care Program (Question No. 2558) Mr Price asked the Minister for Ageing, upon notice, on 8 October 2003: What is the current (a) national, (b) State, and (c) regional waiting time under Home and Community Care programs for (i) lawns and gardening, (ii) podiatry, (iii) physiotherapy, and (iv) diversional therapy. Ms Julie Bishop-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (a), (b) and (c) State and Territory governments are responsible for the day-to-day administration of the Home and Community Care Program (HACC) and are the primary point of contact for HACC service providers and consumers. The Australian Government is not involved in maintaining waiting lists for HACC funded services. Foreign Affairs: Colombia (Question No. 2575) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 9 October 2003: (1) Is he aware of the Colombian Presidential Directive 07 issued on 9 September 1999 which requires all government officials, both civilian and military, to refrain from questioning the legitimacy of human rights organisations and their members; making statements that discredit, persecute, or incite persecution of said organisations; or making public or private declarations that stigmatise the work of these organisations. (2) Is he aware of a speech by Colombian President Álvaro Uribe Velez on 8 September 2003 in which he referred to human rights defenders as “Politickers at the service of terrorism, cowardly waving the human rights banner, who try to give back to terrorism the space that the Armed Forces and ordinary citizens have taken away from them in Colombia” and that “Every time a security strategy is implemented in Colombia to defeat terrorism, when the terrorists start feeling under threat, they immediately dispatch their spokesmen to talk about human rights.”. (3) Is he able to say whether the security of human rights defenders in Colombia has been affected by these statements; if so, (a) in what way, and (b) on what does the Government base this assessment. (4) Has the Government made any representation to the Colombian Government relating to the implications of these public statements; if so, (a) by whom, (b) to whom, (c) when, and (d) what was the response of the Colombian Government; if no representations have been made, why not. (5) Since the speech of 8 September 2003 has the Government made any representation to the Colombian Government in support of human rights organisations operating in Colombia; if so, (a) by whom, (b) to whom, (c) when, and (d) what was the response of the Colombian Government; if no representations have been made, why not. (6) Is he aware of the Colombian Ministry of Defence Directive 09 of 8 July 2003 which requires the State Security Forces to protect the work of human rights organisations and reiterates the applicability of the Presidential Directive 07 and that it “be strictly applied”. (7) Is he aware of a report published on 17 September 2003 by the Office in Colombia of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights titled The Importance of the Protection and Defence of Human Rights Defenders; if so, does the Government support the recommendations of this report. (8) Is he aware of the recent decision by the Colombian Constitutional Court to allow the Colombian Inter-Ecclesiastic Commission for Justice and Peace to bring a lawsuit against General Rito Alejo del Río who was Commander of the XVII Brigade in Urabá between the years of 1995 and 1997; if so, is he able to say when this decision was made. (9) Is he aware of (a) claims by General Jorge Enrique Mora Rangel on 21 August 2003 in which the Community of Cacarica, Chocó, was described as “a site of concentration with barbed wire where nobody can come or go without the order of Justice and Peace” and that “in the settlements there is a constant presence of the FARC”, and (b) the response by the Office of the Human Rights Ombudsman which said that “This does not correspond with reality and could put at risk the communities living there”. (10) Has the Government made any representation to the Colombian Government expressing its concern for the security of members of the Inter-Ecclesiastic Commission for Justice and Peace and for the civilian population of the Community of Cacarica; if so, (a) by whom, (b) to whom, (c) when, and (d) what was the response of the Colombian Government; if not, why not. (1) Yes. (2) I am aware of President Uribe’s speech. In his speech, President Uribe distinguishes between human rights organisations which have his support and respect, and what he termed political activists who act in the service of terrorism under the pretext of human rights. (3) I am not aware of any such effect. (4) No. President Uribe makes it clear in his speech that the Colombian Government is firmly committed to protecting human rights and that human rights organisations have his support. (5) No. Australia’s interest in human rights generally in Colombia is raised as and when appropriate opportunities arise. (6) No. (7) Yes. The Government supports the 2002 United Nations Commission on Human Rights recommendations referred to in the report. (8) No. (9) (a) No; (b) No. (10) No. Australia’s interest in human rights generally in Colombia is raised as and when appropriate opportunities arise. Education: Socioeconomic Status Index (Question No. 2588) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 13 October 2003: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2267 (Hansard, 8 October 2003, page 20856), what preliminary analysis indicates a downward pressure on the rate of increase of non-government school fees. (2) What will be the total cost of Socio-Economic Status (SES) index-based funding before a definitive analysis of the effect of the SES funding model is publicly available. (1) The preliminary analysis is based on the Financial Questionnaire for Non-Government Schools which is an annual collection of financial information from non-government schools receiving Australian Government general recurrent grants. (2) Total funding under the SES funding arrangements for the 2001-2004 quadrennium is outlined below. Increased funding for schools funded on their SES scores is being phased-in at the rate of 25 per cent each year of the quadrennium and, therefore, the SES model will not be fully implemented until the end of 2004. 2001 2002 2003 (Estimated) 2004 (Estimated) $m $m $m $m 3,096 3,364 3,700 4,054

speaker: Dr Nelson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Fisheries: Southern Bluefin Tuna (Question No. 2703) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 4 November 2003: (1) What evidence has he been provided of the current population status of the Southern Bluefin Tuna. (2) Is he aware of the nomination by the Humane Society International of the Southern Bluefin Tuna for listing of the species as endangered under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999. (3) Can he confirm that scientific data suggest that less than five percent of the original global population of the Southern Bluefin Tuna remains; if so, does the Minister support the listing of Southern Bluefin Tuna as an endangered species. (4) What action will the Government take to ensure the long-term survival of the Southern Bluefin Tuna. (1) (2) and (3) I have received a nomination for the listing of the Southern Bluefin Tuna under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (the Act). I have forwarded this nomination to the Threatened Species Scientific Committee for their advice and I await their recommendation. (4) The Australian Government has been party to the Convention for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna since May 1994. One of the objectives of the Convention is to ensure, through appropriate management, the conservation of the global Southern Bluefin Tuna fishery. By being party to this Convention, the Australian Government continues to play an important role in making sure management arrangements are in place to ensure the long term survival of the species. Defence: Personnel (Question No. 2705) Dr Emerson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 November 2003: (1) How many Australians who served in Iraq in Operation Bastille were (a) 18, (b) 19, and (c) 20 years of age. (2) How many Australians who served in Iraq in Operation Falconer were (a) 18, (b) 19, and (c) 20 years of age. (3) Were the rates of pay paid to service personnel who served in these operations when they were under 21 years of age the same as those for service personnel 21 years of age or older in the same or comparable positions; if not, on what basis were the lower rates of pay calculated. (1) (a) 4, (b) 18 (c) 33. (2) (a) 11, (b) 75 (c) 107. Note that some personnel may have served in both Operations and so would be counted twice. (3) Yes.
